container-title: History of the Art of War within the framework of Political History
note: repr. with updated bibliography Oklahoma, 1998) for the Empire. Also useful are H. Parker, The Roman Legions (Oxford, 1928), Y Le Bohec, The Imperial Roman Army (New York, 1994),

still contains much of interest. Well illustrated, more general works include General Sir John Hackett (ed.), Warfare in the Ancient World (London, 1989), and]. Warry, Warfare in the Classical World (London, 1980).
title: GENERAL The literature on the Roman army is truly vast, much of it tucked away in academic journals inaccessible to the general reader. The works listed here will allow the interested reader to begin a deeper study into the subject
The Making of the Roman Army
The Roman Imperial Army
although not all of the latter's conclusions are widely accepted. A little dated and rather too dogmatic

note: H. Elton, Warfare in Roman Europe;, AD 350--425 (Oxford, 1996) is an excellent and wide ranging study of the Later Roman Arm~ More specific studies include ]. Roth, The Logistics of the Roman
title: The Roman Army at WaG 100 BC-AD 200
contains a detailed analysis on operational practices and the nature of battle in the Late Republic and Early empire
Imperial Army at War (264 BC-AD 235
Exploratio: Military and Political Intelligence in the Roman World from the Second Punic War to the Battle of Adrianople

note: Coulston, Roman Military Equipment (London, 1993), ~ Connolly, Greece and Rome at War
title: Military equipment is covered only briefly in this work, but there are a number of excellent books on the subject, notably M
The Armour of Imperial Rome
Recent research in this field is regularly published in the Journal of Roman Military Equipment Studies

container-title: Papers of the British School at Rome
note: in K. Hopwood, Organized Crime in the Ancient World (Swansea, 1999). CHAPTER 2 There are many works on this period and in particular the Punic Wars, of which the best are ]. Lazenby, The First Punic War (London, 1996) and Hannibal's War
title: A good recent survey of Rome's early history is T. Cornell, The Beginnings of Rome. Italy and Rome from the Bronze Age to the Punic Wars (c. 1000-264 BC
There are few books dedicated to the military history of this period, but notable articles include E. Rawson, 'The Literary Sources for the Pre-Marian Roman Army'
'Condottieri and Clansmen: Early Italian Warfare and the State.'
Several interesting articles are included in T
The Second Punic War: A Reappraisal

note: Cambridge Mass., 1940), W Rogers, Greek and Roman Naval Warfare
title: The Roman Art of War under the Republic
Thiel, Studies on the History of Roman Sea-Power in Republican Times
The Seleucid Army
Organization and Tactics in the Great Campaigns

note: W. Harris, War and Imperialism in Republican Rome 327-70 BC (Oxford, 1976), M. Hopkins, Conquerors and Slaves
title: Important contributions on Roman imperialism are to be found in E. Badian, Roman Imperialism in the Late Republic
The Creation of the Roman Frontier

note: Brunt, Italian Manpower, 225 BC-AD 14 (Oxford, 1971), J. Fuller, ]ulius Caesar: Man Soldier and Tyrant (London, 1965), E. Gabba Republican Rome, the Army and the Allies
title: War and Society in the Roman World

title: Military Defeat and Aristocratic Competition in the Middle and Late Republic

note: and A. Johnson, Roman Forts (London, 1983) all cover aspects of the army in this period.
title: The Auxilia of the Roman Imperial Army

note: Alston, Soldier and Society in Roman Egypt (London, 1995), R. Davies, Service in the Roman Army
title: The Emperor and the Roman Army
is good on the political role of the arm~ Daily life is dealt with in R

container-title: The Roman Army in the East
note: A. Ferrill, Roman Imperial Grand Strategy (New York, 1991),

Rome's Desert Frontier from the Air (London, 1990) offers spectacular pictures of many Roman outposts, whilst a good introduction to the copious literature on Hadrian's Wall is D. Breeze and B. Dobson, Hadrians Wall (London, 1987).
title: The Roman Soldier
Legionary Recruitment and Veteran Settlement during the Principate
remains a fine study of recruitment. The Empire's frontiers and the vexed question of Grand Strategy are covered by E. Luttwak, The Grand Strategy of the Roman Empire
The Limits of Empire

note: Ferrill, The Fall of the Roman Empire: The Military Explanation (London, 1986) offers one interpretation of the military problems of Late Antiquit~
title: The Later Roman Empire (Oxford, 1964) still contains a wealth of information concerning Late Antiquit~ P
The Late Roman Army (London, 1996) is a handy introduction, but not always reliable, whilst A

note: presents the meagre evidence for unit size, as does W Treadgold, Byzantium and its Army, 281-1081 (Stansford, 1995).
title: Unit Sizes in the Late Roman Army
